channel.title: Ramadan 2013/2014
channel.description:
This month is Ramadan.
Question: What is Ramadan? Ramadan is the ninth month of the Islamic lunar calendar. Every day during this month, Muslims around the world spend the daylight hours in a complete fast. Answer: During the blessed month of Ramadan, Muslims all over the world abstain from food, drink, and other physical needs during the daylight hours. As a time to purify the soul, refocus attention on God, and practice self-sacrifice, Ramadan is much more than just not eating and drinking.
Muslims are called upon to use this month to re-evaluate their lives in light of Islamic guidance. We are to make peace with those who have wronged us, strengthen ties with family and friends, do away with bad habits -- essentially to clean up our lives, our thoughts, and our feelings. The Arabic word for "fasting" (sawm) literally means "to refrain" - and it means not only refraining from food and drink, but from evil actions, thoughts, and words.
During Ramadan, every part of the body must be restrained. The tongue must be restrained from backbiting and gossip. The eyes must restrain themselves from looking at unlawful things. The hand must not touch or take anything that does not belong to it. The ears must refrain from listening to idle talk or obscene words. The feet must refrain from going to sinful places. In such a way, every part of the body observes the fast.
Therefore, fasting is not merely physical, but is rather the total commitment of the person's body and soul to the spirit of the fast. Ramadan is a time to practice self-restraint; a time to cleanse the body and soul from impurities and re-focus one's self on the worship of God

item.title: Ramadan 2013/2014
item.dc:creator: @goudont goudont
item.description:
@goudont wrote:

Well at the comments that I’m seeing, it’s all about religion. In this month, Ramadan, muslims are forgiven by Allah (God), more than they would be regularly. You can go up to about 28 days (if I’m correct), with out eating. about 18 hours you have to go with out eating or drinking, and ask for forgiveness, it has nothing to do with starving. What happens is, in the morning, Fajr time (around sunrise), you have to eat all you can before the sun comes up, then after that, you can no longer eat until Maghrib (sundown). Each hour that you resist sins and eating, God forgives 1000 sins. It’s like you’re going to a lake, and wash your self 5 times a day. You won’t be dirty right? Now, if you ask God for help in this time of the month, he will take it like you’ve been asking him 1000x, and you’ve been doing everything right 1000x, and he will forgive your sins. So you’ll be clean of your sins. This has nothing to do with hunger you guys (comments), except only when you are actually fasting when you wake up in the morning time. Most of the time, when you fast, you’re doing it for your selves, because in the Holy Book the Qu’ran, it is said that the evil and Satan are supposed to be locked up for those who fast, because Satan stays away from those who listen to God. If you complain about not eating everyday until around 8 or 9 pm, you know that people do a lot for religion and beliefs. And those beliefs are amazingly strong.
